Examples of Differentiated Instruction in Writing

The YouTube video below of Jeffery Wilhelm, Professor, Boise State University, explains the gradual release model and ways that it can implemented in the classroom, accommodating learner differences and levels of readiness. As you watch the video, consider how you might use the "I Do, We Do, You Do" model in your classes.

Transcript of Presentation

Examples of Differentiated Instruction in Math

Example 1 - Video: Teaching with Question

In a video, Teaching with Questions, curriculum developer Steve Hinds depicts instruction that allows students to develop independent thinking, explain their thought processes and approaches to problem solving, and communicate with one another and with the teacher. At the time of filming Steve Hinds was the Mathematics Staff Developer in Adult Literacy/GED Program and College Transition Program at the City University of New York and he is currently the Mathematics Curriculum Developer for the City Colleges of Chicago. 

Example 2: Differentiated Learning in the Math Classroom

Eighth grade math teacher David Saurez and his colleagues developed a tiered instructional approach to work with their students.  They organized instruction into thematic units.  For each math skill within a unit, they determined activities that would demonstrate a foundational understanding, an intermediate understanding, and an advanced understanding of the concepts, color coded as Green, Blue, Black.  For a portion of each class period, students select assignments to work on within the level that is challenging without overwhelming them.  This approach allows students more autonomy and reveals a progression of how the concepts are connected.  For example, for a lesson on Understanding Slope, David Saurez provided the following three assignment options to his students.

Topic Green Level
(foundational)		Blue Level
(intermediate)		Black Level
(advanced)
Understanding Slope Understanding Slope Find the slope of the line passing through the following pair of points: (-4, 6) and (-3, 2). Find a so that the line connecting the points (-2, -3) and (2, 5) is parallel to the line connecting the points (6, a) and (0, 4). If a > 1, what must be true about b so that the line passing through points (a, b) and (1, -3) has a negative slope?

Source: Suarez, D. (2007). When students choose the challenge. Educational Leadership, 65(3), 60–65.
